item.description: Tram-Spel (Tram game) is about horsecars and was made in the early 1900's by Werner & Schumann, Berlin. It is typical roll and move board game. The first player who cross 63 stops, wins the game.

Vietnam Solitaire Special Edition is an expanded edition of the original Vietnam Solitaire that contains both the original game (with all new artwork) and a reimplementation by Steve Kling with expanded rules, new scenarios, and new counters. While primarily a solitaire game, the special edition also contains optional two player rules.

In the Special Edition, the player controls US and South Vietnamese forces and must battle the Vietcong and North Vietnamese Army to control as many regions of Vietnam as possible. The game is played by deploying US and South Vietnamese forces, napalm, and air units on a map of Vietnam. The AI (or an optional second player) controls the North Vietnamese forces through movement and attack rules.

Victory is determined by controlling at least three regions of Vietnam for a majority of the game. Unlike in the original game, the eventual victory of the North Vietnamese is not a foregone conclusion.

The Special Edition contains new types of units, a greater variety of of combat points, and two new scenarios - "Tet 1968" and "Fall of South Vietnam".

The Take is about crooked cops taking money. It is played over the course of several rounds. Each round, each player takes a bill(card) worth between 1 and 5 thousand dollars. In the second half of the game each player gets an opportunity to take an action after all players have taken their money for the round.

There are three ways to win the game:

 If the deck of cards runs out, the player with the most money wins at the end of the final round.
 If a player correctly accuses a player of having the most money,the accuser immediately wins.
 If a player correctly accuses another player of having the least money, the player with the most money wins.




There are 4 basic actions that players can take by spending money from their hand.

 Stakeout: Adjust turn order.
 Audit: Look at another player's cards.
 Accuse: Accuse a player of having the most or least money.
 Defame: Block a player from taking an action.

(from the ATO website "Black Swans" section)
Against the Odds broke new ground with the 2010 Annual. Four Roads to Moscow included four different, complete games from four top designers, each one taking their own approach to cover Barbarossa. There have been “quad games” before, but never like this.

While many people are thrilled to get all four, we figured a few folks might have a favored designer and only want that game. We aim to please. So, if you want to try just one or two of the “Four Roads,” the option is here.

Hitler Turns East by Ted Raicer is a classic-style, hex-and-counter wargame that uses chit-pull to keep things fluid. Hitler Turns East focuses on the difficulties of armies cooperating with each other, either for political or personal reasons (and Barbarossa saw lots on both sides).

The new printing of Hitler Turns East comes with 144 updated die-cut 9/16" counters, and a 17" x 22" full color map, plus updated rules and charts.

In Dystopian: the manhunt, one to four players assume the role of special agents of the Dystopia Police Department (called Sector 9), with the goal of investigating a murder case, finding the criminal, among four suspects and, eventually, catching him, it or her, before he gets away.
The agents will move around the megalopolis of Dystopia, investigating the numerous locations (distributed among districts and suburbs) meeting people, talking to them, gaining and finding hints and leads that make the investigation progress, bringing them closer and closer to the murderer.
Dystopia is a City controlled by two rival Corporations (Varcom and Infracorp), that are in the business of AI-Roids: artificially intelligent robots that live with the humans.
Dystopia features a plethora of many different locations, where the players will have to conduct their investigation.

Dystopian: the manhunt features the following mechanics: worker placement, variable player powers, action selection, network building, cooperative/solitaire play, press your luck.

The players will have to roll dice, and allocate them on their agent's sheet to gain these resources: 
1) warrants: to enter a location
2) attack: to respond to an attack from an encounter
3) evade: to hide from an attack from an encounter
4) interact: to interact with encounters or locations
5) analyze: to analyze hints and gain evidence about who committed the crime

Such resources will be used to deal with encounters the players will meet around the city, to advance their agent's abilities, ultimately, to catch the suspect who is found guilty.

The game is divided in 2 stages: the first is the Search, where players have to discovered who, among the 4 suspects, committed the crime; and the second, the Chase, where the suspect tries to hide in Dystopia, and it's up to the agents to seize him (it or her).

The animals on the farm are playing a game of "red light/green light", but they decided to change a few of the rules without telling Bonaparte the pig! Are you ready for the surprise?

In 1,2,3! Now you see me..., one of the players takes a bunch of animals, lets them fall on the table, and asks the rest of the players to close their eyes. While nobody is looking, he takes an action with the animals (move an animal, add an animal, hide an animal, or trade places with two animals), then tells his friends to open their eyes.

Let's see if they know which animal (or animals) took the action! Each player who gives the right answer scores 1 point, then it starts all over again!

item.description:
Rush is the primary title.

The entire title would be...

Colorado's Green

Rush

It is (as the name implies) about the 21st century rush currently underway in Colorado, meaning...

The legalization of Marijuana.

It is a game about trying to make money in this crazy industry.

It's like the Wild-Wild-West all over again!!!

Rush is an economic game that involves the fact that law enforcement is always angling to shut down your enterprise.

We here at Common Man Games have always taken a special interest in games that are themed after modern-day subject matters, and involve Law Enforcement.

We think this is a very interesting topic, and one that is evolving right before our eyes.

We began work on this game back in 2013 and hoped to release it in 2014, but getting it right has been a long slow process and one we don't want to "Rush" (sorry), so exactly when it will be released is a tricky question to answer, but please...

Stay Tuned!

You have just been promoted to lead the newly-formed Harbinger Project – a secret collection of the top allied minds, brought together in an effort to defeat the enemy through foreknowledge of their actions. By intercepting enemy transmissions and breaking enemy codes, you will be able to make the best use of your military might against the oncoming invasion and show the enemy the true meaning of “forewarned is forearmed.”

The Harbinger Project is a solitaire game using two 8-sided dice and two printed playsheets. As head of the codebreaking branch, your job is to decide how best to use your time before the enemy invades. The enemy will invade random locations with random unit types. Your job is to use your dice and wits to decipher and break the enemy codes, thus allowing you to learn the details of the enemy's plan before you assign units to defend. You must also split your time between defending important structures, enciphering friendly codes, and recruiting new units to defend.

The enemy will make 6 invasions in their approach to your capital. They have reserves of 14 of each of 4 different unit types. Your job is to destroy all enemy units before they reach your capital.

Castle Rising is a German-style board game in which you choose an economic strategy to try to create the most prosperous kingdom. Players acquire resources (food, wood, stone, metal and gold) to train troops and construct buildings to earn benefits at different stages of the game and victory points to win the game.

Players can acquire resources in three ways, the main one being through your peasants, with each player starting with three. You decide which resources to produce, but some are easier to get than others, so you can play it safe or risk trying for a few more precious resources. You can also gain resources through rangers, which you must first train, which takes several units of food and wood.

The last way to gain resources is through the bidding phase. Each turn, all players bid secretly on one of five different resource bundles.
